instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Greg's parents reveal that they are going away for the weekend and taking Manny with them.
2) Rodrick takes advantage of this and informs Greg that they are throwing a party together, reminding him of The Heffley Brothers.
3) Rodrick sends the "party text" on his phone and tells Greg to bring his "friends" over.
4) Greg invites Rowley over to help, but they both end up doing all the work while Rodrick sits and directs.
5) He locks them in the basement after telling them to get an extra table.
6) Greg loosens the doorknob and takes photos of the party as "blackmail".
7) In the morning, they are let out and Rowley runs home while Greg confronts Rodrick over what happened.
8) They suddenly get a call from their mother Susan, who informs them that Manny got sick, and they are coming home right away.
9) Rodrick tells Greg to clean up, but Greg refuses.
10) Rodrick finally gets Greg to change his mind and quickly clean up the house.
11) As they think they are done, the bathroom door slides, revealing 'Rodrick Rules' on the bathroom door just as Susan, Frank, and Manny arrive.
12) Greg tries to wipe the writing off the door, but it turns out to be permanent ink.
13) The brothers quickly remove the bedroom door to Rodrick's room, and switch Rodrick's door with the replacement to the bathroom door after panicking.
14) Following the incident, Frank makes the two boys rake the leaves.
15) Greg demands Rodrick give him advice in return for helping clean up the party.
16) Rodrick gives in and tells him about his 'Rodrick Rules' which deal with getting things done without making an effort.
17) Greg corrects that 'Rodrick Rules' should be 'Rodrick's Rules', but Rodrick's first rule was "no apostrophes".
18) After raking leaves, Greg quickly becomes impatient but is calmed down when Rodrick teaches him how to play the drums.
19) Greg meets his fellow bandmates of Löded Diper, one of whom is actually a 30-something year old man, Bill, who are going to enter a talent show.
20) Greg is also in it, but is assisting Rowley with his magic act, something which he does not think will be a hit.
21) Frank suspects that the boys are hiding something, but Susan is happy to see them getting along.
22) When Frank asks about Rodrick's "bathroom door" not being locked, Greg covers and claims that he accidentally slammed it too hard, explaining why it does not lock properly.
23) Frank and Susan are going away for the weekend again, but this time, they will leave the boys with Grandpa at the nursing home, which Rodrick seems overly eager about.
24) At the nursing home, Rodrick reveals that the board games contain plenty of Mom Bucks they can use back at home.
25) He gives some to Greg, but his pants get wet during a game, and he is forced to change in the lobby bathroom.
26) Greg accidentally ends up in the women's room where he gets accused of being a peeping tom.
27) A chase through the old folks home ensues, but he manages to get back to the room.
28) Later, Grandpa tells Greg that he knows that he and Rodrick did not want to come, but he admires that they hang out, something that Frank fails to do with his brothers.
29) The next school day, Rowley reminds Greg that he needed to do his life science project and he rushes to Rodrick for help.
30) He gives him his old life science project on the condition that he hand over some Mom Bucks.
31) Greg does so, but upon arriving at school realizes that it is a failed project about plants sneezing.
32) Greg angrily reveals his blackmail to Rodrick and demands he pay up in Mom Bucks.
33) Rodrick gives $200 but, he accidentally bumps into Susan, who sees the photos, and she and Frank punish both the boys.
34) One of Rodrick's punishments in particular is that he is not allowed to perform in the talent show, though Greg is still forced to perform with Rowley.
35) When Greg tells Rodrick he didn't expect this, Rodrick angrily tells that never would have happened if he hadn't "snitched".
36) As payback, Rodrick reveals that he took photos of the pictures in Greg's diary about the restroom incident and threatens to send them to his friends who will send them to their siblings.
37) They get the phone away from Rodrick, but Rowley accidentally sends the photos.
38) To Greg's surprise, the story at school got twisted to being about Greg winning the top prize at a bingo competition and making a big getaway, making him popular.
39) Greg is still annoyed however as he has to do the talent show with Rowley, but just before entering, Löded Diper approaches Greg about being their new drummer, as their replacement drummer Larry loves magic and would not mind switching places with him.
40) Greg starts to question whether he should drum or not, but after Rodrick makes a scathing remark to him, he agrees.
41) Upon seeing Rodrick leaving the show upset, Greg goes out to talk to him and explains that he simply wanted him to be proud of him and was worried they will grow apart.
42) Rodrick tells Greg that he does care about him and that they will continue to hang out together.
43) Greg gives Rodrick his position as drummer back, despite his parents' wishes and returns to Löded Diper.
44) Frank and Susan extend Greg's punishment, but Greg says it's worth it and Grandpa then commends Frank for raising two good brothers while Susan excitedly dances to the band's song.
45) Rowley's magic show ends up winning the competition while Löded Diper gains a wider audience thanks to Susan.
46) Despite their differences, Greg and Rodrick's relationship improves.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
### 1. Identify the Protagonist and Major Events
The protagonist of the story is Greg. Five major events in the story are:
1. Greg's parents reveal they are going away, and Rodrick suggests throwing a party (sentences 1-3).
2. The party happens, and Greg takes photos as blackmail after being locked in the basement (sentences 4-7).
3. Greg and Rodrick clean up the house after their mother calls to say they are coming home early (sentences 8-10).
4. Greg gets involved with Rodrick's band, Löded Diper, and considers joining them for a talent show (sentences 19-41).
5. The talent show concludes with Greg deciding to drum with Löded Diper, and his relationship with Rodrick improves (sentences 42-46).

### 2. Describe the Protagonist's State at Each Event
- **Event 1:** Greg starts in a relatively neutral state, learning his parents are leaving and then getting dragged into Rodrick's party plan. His condition could be considered as falling into a potential dilemma due to Rodrick's influence.
- **Event 2:** Greg's state worsens as he is exploited and locked in the basement by Rodrick, but he manages to gather blackmail material, indicating a potential for future leverage or improvement in his condition.
- **Event 3:** Greg's condition improves slightly as he and Rodrick clean up, avoiding immediate punishment, but he is still at odds with Rodrick. This shows a recovery from the previous low point.
- **Event 4:** Greg's state improves further as he becomes involved with Löded Diper and considers joining them, showing an increase in his social standing and personal fulfillment. However, this also introduces tension with Rodrick, complicating his condition.
- **Event 5:** Greg's condition improves significantly as he decides to drum with Löded Diper, and more importantly, his relationship with Rodrick improves, showing a positive resolution to their conflicts and an overall better state than at the beginning of the story.

### 3. Classify the Story Arc Type
The story arc can be classified by analyzing the protagonist's condition throughout the major events. Initially, Greg falls into a dilemma (the party and being locked in the basement), then finds a way out and improves his condition (cleaning up and avoiding punishment), faces another challenge (the tension with Rodrick over the band), and finally ends in a better state (improved relationship with Rodrick and involvement with the band). This pattern of falling into a dilemma, recovering, facing another challenge, and ultimately ending in a better state aligns with the **Double Man in a Hole** story arc, where the protagonist faces two cycles of dilemma and recovery.

### 4. Determined Story Arc Type
Double Man in a Hole

### 1. Identifying the Protagonist and Major Events

The protagonists in the story are Madison Carter and Noah Mitchell, who are both central characters around whom the plot revolves. 

Five major events in the story are:
- Event 1: The introduction of Madison and Noah amidst their high-pressure jobs at Two Peak Enterprises, with a budding romance (sentences 1-4).
- Event 2: The discovery of a discrepancy in a billion-dollar deal that raises alarm bells, leading to a secret investigation (sentence 9).
- Event 3: The realization that their respected boss is behind the corruption, followed by swift and vicious retaliation (sentences 15-16).
- Event 4: Madison and Noah securing evidence and taking a moral stand to expose their boss's unscrupulous activities (sentences 18-20).
- Event 5: The aftermath of exposing the corruption, leading to the downfall of Two Peak Enterprises and the protagonists deciding to leave the world of finance (sentences 24-26).

### 2. Describing the Protagonist's State at Each Event

- **Event 1**: At the beginning, Madison and Noah are in a high-status position professionally but face the challenge of keeping their relationship secret. Their condition is relatively stable, with a positive personal development (budding romance) amidst professional demands.
- **Event 2**: Upon discovering the discrepancy, they move into a state of tension and risk, as their investigation could lead to professional and personal repercussions. Their condition becomes more precarious compared to the initial stability.
- **Event 3**: With the revelation of their boss's corruption and the subsequent retaliation, Madison and Noah's situation worsens significantly. They face not only professional jeopardy but also physical danger, marking a low point in their condition.
- **Event 4**: By securing evidence and deciding to expose the corruption, Madison and Noah take a significant risk but also embark on a path of moral redemption. Their condition starts to improve as they take control of their situation and stand up for what is right, despite the risks.
- **Event 5**: After the exposure and the downfall of Two Peak Enterprises, Madison and Noah emerge as heroes and decide to leave the aggressive world of finance for a quieter life. This marks a significant improvement in their condition, as they achieve a form of personal and professional liberation, albeit with a note of suspense at the very end.

### 3. Classifying the Story Arc Type

The story arc type can be classified based on how the protagonist's condition changes throughout the narrative. Starting from a relatively stable and high point (successful careers and a budding romance), Madison and Noah fall into a dilemma (discovery of corruption and subsequent dangers) and then find a way out by taking a moral stand and exposing the truth. This leads to an ultimate improvement in their condition, as they transition to a new, presumably better life, leaving behind the corruption and stress of their previous world.

This pattern fits the **Man in a Hole** story arc, where the protagonist falls into a difficult situation but eventually recovers and ends up in a better state than where they began. The key elements are the initial fall into trouble (discovery of corruption and retaliation), the struggle to overcome it (investigation and moral stand), and the eventual rise to a better condition (exposure of truth and new life).

### 4. Determined Story Arc Type

Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Emily Meyers and Luke Edmunds, analysts at the cutthroat Manhattan hedge fund One Crest Capital, are in a secret passionate relationship unbeknownst to their coworkers.
2) Luke proposes to Emily while at his brother's wedding, and she happily accepts.
3) The next day, one of the company's portfolio managers is fired.
4) Emily tells Luke she overheard her colleagues mentioning Luke being considered as a replacement and they celebrate that night.
5) However, at a late-night meeting with Campbell, the firm's CEO, Emily learns she will be receiving the promotion.
6) Emily reluctantly breaks the news to Luke, but he expresses his support.
7) As Emily settles into her new job, Luke's resentment over not being promoted becomes increasingly apparent, leading to tensions in his relationship with Emily.
8) Luke becomes consumed with the work of a self-help guru coaching people on how to assert themselves in the workplace.
9) When Emily questions his choice to spend $3,000 on the course, Luke suggests she could benefit from becoming more assertive, to which she becomes defensive.
10) Luke rebuffs Emily's attempts to initiate sex and goes to bed.
11) While out for drinks with Campbell and Paul, a senior executive at the fund, Emily learns Campbell is seeking to get rid of Luke, considering him ineffectual.
12) Emily attempts to advocate more for Luke in the workplace, but it backfires when Luke makes a poor trading call that loses the company $25 million, leading to Campbell insulting her.
13) Luke attempts to rectify himself by feeding Emily insider information confirming the alleged collapse of a company whose stock the fund can short.
14) Concerned about the trade being illegal, Emily recommends Campbell to short another company, which proves successful.
15) When the short sale is closed, Emily receives a $575,000 commission check.
16) Emily considers celebrating her success with Luke, who is in her office after hours to discuss strategies for future trades but opts to go to a strip club with her male co-workers.
17) She comes home intoxicated while Luke, after seeing the check, has no interest in having sex with her.
18) When another portfolio manager is fired the next day, Luke wants Emily to recommend him for the role, but she hints Campbell is not interested in promoting him.
19) Luke goes to Campbell's office and makes an elaborate speech pledging his loyalty to him, only to learn Campbell has already hired a new portfolio manager.
20) That night, Emily learns her mother had planned a surprise engagement party for them that Friday.
21) A drunken Luke accuses Emily of stealing his job, but Emily reveals Campbell wanted to fire him, leading Luke to storm out.
22) The next day, while Emily, Campbell, and Paul pitch to overseas investors, Luke barges into the conference room intoxicated and causes a scene, berating Campbell for denying him a promotion and revealing his relationship with Emily, which has violated company policy since her promotion.
23) An infuriated Emily is unable to reach Luke over the phone, only to find him at the engagement party.
24) The two argue in front of their families, and Emily smashes a bottle on Luke's head when he suggests she had traded sexual favors for the promotion.
25) Emily retreats to a bathroom where Luke finds her and the two argue before having sex.
26) During sex, Luke forces Emily forward twice, causing her face to slam against the bathroom counter.
27) Emily tells Luke to stop, but he does not.
28) The next morning, to protect her job, Emily tells Campbell she was being stalked by Luke and they were never in a relationship.
29) Emily returns home to find Luke there, having packed up his belongings and planning to move in with his brother.
30) Infuriated by his nonchalant attitude and demanding an apology for raping her, Emily threatens Luke with a knife.
31) She attacks Luke with the knife until he apologizes and breaks down crying.
32) Luke begs for her forgiveness and Emily orders him to leave before dropping the knife and smiling.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
To analyze the story arc, let's first identify the protagonist and major events in the story.

1. **Protagonist Identification and Major Events**:
   - The protagonist of the story is Emily Meyers.
   - Five major events in the story are:
     1. Emily learns she will be receiving the promotion (Event 5).
     2. Luke's resentment over not being promoted leads to tensions in his relationship with Emily (Event 7).
     3. Emily attempts to advocate more for Luke in the workplace, but it backfires (Event 12).
     4. Emily receives a $575,000 commission check after a successful trade (Event 15).
     5. Emily threatens Luke with a knife, demanding an apology for raping her, and eventually, Luke apologizes and leaves (Events 30-32).

2. **Protagonist's State at Each Event**:
   - **Event 5**: Emily's state improves significantly as she receives the promotion, indicating a rise in her professional status and potentially her personal confidence.
   - **Event 7**: Emily's state begins to deteriorate as the tension in her relationship with Luke increases due to his resentment. This introduces a personal conflict that complicates her otherwise successful professional life.
   - **Event 12**: Emily's state worsens both professionally and personally. Her attempt to help Luke backfires, leading to professional embarrassment and further strain on their relationship.
   - **Event 15**: Emily's state improves professionally with the receipt of the commission check, indicating a peak in her career success. However, this event also marks a point where her personal relationship with Luke continues to deteriorate.
   - **Events 30-32**: Emily's state hits a low point personally and professionally. She has been raped by Luke, her professional success is tainted by the knowledge that Luke accuses her of trading sexual favors for her promotion, and she is forced to confront the end of their relationship in a violent and traumatic manner.

3. **Story Arc Classification**:
   The story starts with Emily in a relatively good state, being in a secret relationship and having a promising career. She then experiences a significant professional rise with her promotion but faces personal and professional challenges as her relationship with Luke deteriorates and she faces complications at work. Despite achieving professional success (receiving the commission check), her personal life descends into violence and trauma, culminating in a dramatic confrontation with Luke. This pattern, where the protagonist starts in a relatively high state (in terms of personal relationship and career prospects), rises professionally but faces significant personal and professional setbacks, leading to a drastic downfall in personal terms, aligns with the **Riches to Rags** story arc type. The key characteristic of this arc is the overall decline from a high starting point to a lower ending point, both in personal and professional terms, despite temporary successes.

4. **Determined Story Arc Type**:
Riches to Rags

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) On a balmy evening in the vibrant city of Barcelona, an ethereal figure emerges on the weather-beaten, cracked rooftop of a forgotten edifice in Girona.
2) This enigmatic silhouette is only known by his lethal moniker, the Slayer.
3) His laser-sharp gaze navigates from the amplified image in his state-of-the-art sniper scope, seamlessly shifting to feast on the simmering glow emitted from a plush suite within the renowned Ritz Carlton hotel, dwarfed by the vibrant cityscape.
4) The Slayer's encrypted Motorola phone springs to life, as it pulsates in his pocket.
5) The caller ID reveals a shroud of secrecy - the enigmatic Mr. X.
6) Their relationship is cloaked in professionalism, devoid of any personal connections, their identities veiled behind anonymity.
7) Digitized images of a feared crime lord, El Patron, alias 'The Boss' flash across the mobile screen in tandem with Mr. X’s veiled briefing - a clear instruction of assassination.
8) This kingpin's reign of fear extends its vipers over the beautiful city of Barcelona, a ruthless overlord tracing back to heinous acts of torture, ruthless drug trafficking, and blood-curdling murders.
9) The Slayer's past, a black and white reel of chilling experiences of a life he wants to leave behind, unexpectedly brims at the corner of his mind.
10) These blurred memories hint at traumatic experiences that he longs to repress.
11) Amidst this conundrum of the past, a poignant image of Maria, a mesmerizing Spanish belle clutching a heart-shaped locket, flashes before him.
12) Her portrait underlines a love story that the Slayer guards desperately amidst his blood-stained career.
13) Maria's symbolic laughter rekindles the nurturing aspect of Slayer’s life, where shedding his brutal past isn’t just a mere glimmer.
14) Her naive gaze draws out the assurance of a peaceful life he had solemnly promised Maria.
15) Resistance against performing another ruthless assassination engulfs the Slayer in a whirlwind of self-conflict.
16) Grinding this emotional surge into fuel, Slayer's inner turmoil spring into action, spurred by his promises to Maria.
17) Straddling the fence that encapsulates his unwillingness to kill yet again and the tantalizing allure of a seven-figure reward along with the possibility of starting afresh, the Slayer finds himself at a crossroads.
18) His mission rolls out like a merciless stub of a cigar, burned ruthily - El Patron’s fortified bodyguards, poised like a ring of iron forming an impenetrable fortress around him.
19) Shadowing from dilapidated buildings and executing precision profiling amidst stolen blueprints of the Ritz Carlton, the Slayer sketches out his lethal plan.
20) The brewing storm of suspicion in Maria's mind is evident as she grapples with the reality of the Slayer's mysterious absences and unexplained wounds.
21) The stress simmers over the edge, as a heated confrontation ensues in their shared apartment located in the Gothic Quarter.
22) She dreads the scent of gunpowder and betrayal masked and veiled behind false promises.
23) Although Maria braces herself for a lie, a flicker of hope pushes her to plead with the Slayer to abandon his deadly intent.
24) The internal battle within him is evident in her demeanour, where she lets her tears pool in her eyes, softly urging Slayer to veer away from his bloody course.
25) The course of the game takes an unexpected twist when a jittery local informant leaks an encoded warning to the Police about an assassination assignment set for El Patron.
26) The cityscape instantly metamorphoses into a tactical battlefield, the glaring lights from patrolling police cars casting ominous shadows onto the ancient city walls.
27) The feud turns horribly personal when El Patron's seasoned entourage kidnaps Maria, entrapping her in the Slayer's vortex.
28) A primal, ear-deafening roar and a deep-seeded tenacity wake within the Slayer, pushing him towards a bloodthirsty retribution.
29) The Slayer plots an audacious mission to save Maria, setting the expansive suite at the Ritz Carlton as his battlefield where time waits for no one.
30) Underneath glistening chandeliers, the Slayer manoeuvres like a shadow through guards and security cameras.
31) Every step he takes mirrors his deadly intentions.
32) The climax ensues as the Slayer wades through a heart-stopping fight - deceiving relentless police, brushing teeth with death, and hovering closer to his enemies.
33) Cornering El Patron in the glittering bathroom of the penthouse, the Slayer locks his exit route with a deadly gaze.
34) Trudging out through the smoky scene, the Slayer limps out from the gold-accented duel scene, his fresh battle scars are a testament to his title, leaving El Patron motionless amidst a storm of shattered glass.
35) Urgent sirens ring as the dispatched police officers swarm into the chaotic crime scene, their blue-flashing lights transforming the previously opulent suite into a turmoil-filled hurricane.
36) Maria's trembling arms embrace the blood-drenched Slayer, her emerald green eyes, tear-stricken, silently pleading for his survival.
37) Amidst the chaos, a sympathetic cop, Officer Lopez, silently assists their escape.
38) Even though his loyalty to the badge is paramount, the unfolding tale draws out an unusual kindness as he provides them with a nondescript black getaway van.
39) The Slayer whisks Maria and himself to an abandoned cathedral located on the city's bare outskirts.
40) Distressed and desperate, the towering bell tower stands aloof looming over their shared anguish.
41) Amid the silence of the cathedral, their flicker of renewed hope shrivels away as Maria and Slayer, fatigued and dwindling, collapse on the hard floor.
42) The morning rays break, glimpsing on the runaways resting in the back pew of the austere chapel, enmeshed within eerie fog and antique stones.
43) As each minute turns into an eternity of fear and uncertainty dangling on their survival, Maria and Slayer flees one more time, disappearing into the veil of thick towering pine woods located behind the cathedral.
44) With the vanishing criminals, the city breathes out relief.
45) Sultanah streets resuming their vibrancy, the collective release of the populace echoes through the city.
46) As the televised report fades out, a profound proclamation sits heavy in the viewers' minds.
47) A beacon of a fresh start for Maria and Slayer, released from the shackles of their fraught past highlights the dawn of a new era.

### 1. Identifying the Protagonist and Major Events

The protagonist of the story is the Slayer, an enigmatic figure known for his lethal abilities. Five major events in the story are:

1. **The Assignment**: The Slayer receives a mission from Mr. X to assassinate El Patron (sentence 7).
2. **The Confrontation with Maria**: The Slayer faces a heated confrontation with Maria, who is suspicious of his activities and pleas with him to abandon his deadly intent (sentence 21).
3. **Maria's Kidnapping**: El Patron's entourage kidnaps Maria, drawing the Slayer into a personal feud (sentence 27).
4. **The Rescue Mission**: The Slayer embarks on a mission to save Maria, leading to a confrontation with El Patron and his guards (sentence 29).
5. **The Escape**: The Slayer and Maria escape the chaotic crime scene with the help of Officer Lopez and flee into the unknown (sentence 38).

### 2. Describing the Protagonist's State and Changes

- **At the Assignment**: The Slayer is in a state of professional engagement, receiving a mission that aligns with his skills but also triggers memories of his past and his desire to leave it behind. His state is one of internal conflict but with a clear professional direction.
- **At the Confrontation with Maria**: The Slayer's state worsens as he faces emotional turmoil. His relationship with Maria and her pleas for him to change his ways deepen his internal conflict, making his situation more complicated and emotionally challenging.
- **At Maria's Kidnapping**: The Slayer's state becomes one of desperation and urgency. The personal nature of the conflict escalates his emotional investment, and he is driven by a desire for rescue and retribution.
- **At the Rescue Mission**: The Slayer's state is one of determination and focus. Despite the risks, he is resolute in his mission to save Maria, indicating a peak in his emotional and professional commitment.
- **At the Escape**: The Slayer's state improves as he and Maria escape, indicating a move towards a better situation. They are no longer in immediate danger, and there's a glimmer of hope for a new beginning, symbolized by their fleeing into the unknown.

### 3. Classifying the Story Arc Type

Based on the protagonist's condition throughout the story, it can be observed that the Slayer starts in a situation of internal conflict due to his past and his relationship with Maria. As the story progresses, he faces a significant downturn with Maria's kidnapping, which complicates his situation and forces him into a dangerous rescue mission. However, he manages to rescue Maria, and they escape together, indicating an improvement in his situation from the start.

The story arc type that best fits this progression is the **Man in a Hole**. This is because the Slayer falls into a dilemma (Maria's kidnapping and the ensuing conflict) and finds a way out (rescuing Maria and escaping), ending in a better state than when he started (with hope for a new beginning with Maria). The **Man in a Hole** story arc is characterized by the protagonist's condition worsening before it improves, which aligns with the Slayer's journey from internal conflict, through desperation and danger, to eventual escape and the possibility of redemption.

### 4. Determined Story Arc Type

Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) A professional assassin known only as the Killer stakes out a Parisian hotel room.
2) He prepares to use a sniper rifle to kill a target who will check into the hotel room at an unknown time.
3) While waiting for the target, he eats, practices yoga, listens to music, and talks on the phone with his handler, an attorney, and his former university law professor, Edward "Eddie" Hodges.
4) The target arrives with a dominatrix and the Killer shoots but misses, accidentally shooting the dominatrix.
5) He flees, evading the police and disposing of his equipment.
6) He then flies to the United States.
7) The Killer returns to his hideout in the Dominican Republic to find it has been broken into and his girlfriend Magdala has been attacked.
8) She is in the ICU of a hospital, with her brother watching over her.
9) He says that Magdala was interrogated and tortured by two assassins but managed to injure one of them and escape.
10) The Killer tracks down Leo, the taxi driver who drove the assassins to the Killer's home by breaking into the company he works for.
11) Leo identifies one of the assassins, a strong man with a limp leg, nicknamed "The Brute", and a woman who resembled a Q-Tip, known as "The Expert".
12) The Killer shoots Leo and seeks to track down the two assassins.
13) The Killer travels to Hodges' office in New Orleans, Louisiana, and enters the building disguised as a custodian.
14) After forcing Dolores, Hodges' secretary, to restrain her boss and herself, the Killer destroys their electronics.
15) As Hodges attempts to get the Killer to leave, the Killer shoots him in the chest with a nail gun to torture the names of the hitmen out of him.
16) However, Hodges doesn't reveal the information and dies quicker than the Killer anticipated.
17) Dolores offers to show the Killer the assassins' identities in her paper files in her home, asking in return that the Killer give her a non-suspicious death so her children can claim a life insurance payout.
18) After receiving the names at her home, the Killer breaks his rule not to show empathy, he snaps her neck and shoves her down a flight of stairs, making her death look like an accident.
19) He then disposes of Hodges' body.
20) The Killer drives to St. Petersburg, Florida, where he confronts the Brute, whom he identifies by his limp.
21) At night, he breaks into the Brute's home to kill him, but he is blindsided and tackled, ensuing a fight during which the Brute realizes who the Killer is before the Killer shoots him and sets his house on fire with a Molotov cocktail.
22) The Killer travels to Beacon, New York, and confronts The Expert "Q-Tip" assassin in a gourmet restaurant.
23) Appearing to accept her fate, the Expert offers to share with him a "last supper" of whiskey, during which she questions the Killer's motivations.
24) They leave the restaurant and go to a park, and after the Expert appears to slip down a small flight of ice-covered stairs, the Expert asks the Killer to help her up, but the Killer shoots her, revealing that she was concealing a knife.
25) The Killer travels to Chicago, to kill billionaire venture capitalist Henderson "Clay" Claybourne.
26) He uses tools bought on Amazon to enter his penthouse.
27) Confronting him, the Killer demands to know why he ordered the assassins to come after him.
28) Claybourne says that he has no personal problem with him and, as a first-time client of a hitman, agreed to pay Hodges for "the trail to be scrubbed".
29) The Killer spares Claybourne, but he promises him a slow death if Claybourne ever targets him again.
30) The Killer returns to the Dominican Republic and sits next to a recovering Magdala.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
### 1. Identifying the Protagonist and Major Events

The protagonist of the story is the Killer, a professional assassin. Five major events in the story are:

1. The Killer misses his target and accidentally shoots the dominatrix (sentence 4).
2. The Killer finds out his girlfriend, Magdala, has been attacked and is in the ICU (sentence 7).
3. The Killer identifies the assassins who attacked Magdala, "The Brute" and "The Expert" (sentence 11).
4. The Killer confronts and kills "The Brute" and "The Expert" (sentences 21-24).
5. The Killer spares Claybourne's life but warns him of consequences if he targets the Killer again and then returns to Magdala (sentences 26-30).

### 2. Describing the Protagonist's State at Each Event

- **Event 1:** The Killer's state changes from being in control and prepared for a mission to facing failure and having to flee. This is a downturn in his condition as he not only misses his target but also draws unwanted attention.
- **Event 2:** Upon learning of Magdala's attack, the Killer's state worsens. He is now not only a fugitive but also personally affected, showing a vulnerability. This event deepens his predicament.
- **Event 3:** Identifying the attackers slightly improves the Killer's state because he now has a lead to act on. However, he is still in a precarious situation and faces danger.
- **Event 4:** Successfully confronting and killing "The Brute" and "The Expert" significantly improves the Killer's state. He has avenged Magdala and removed immediate threats to himself, showing a recovery from his previous vulnerabilities.
- **Event 5:** The Killer's decision to spare Claybourne and return to Magdala indicates a further improvement in his state. He has resolved the immediate threats and is in a position to rebuild and protect what is important to him.

### 3. Classifying the Story Arc Type

The story arc type can be classified based on how the protagonist's condition changes throughout the narrative. Initially, the Killer is in a position of control and skill, but he faces a significant downturn with the failure of his mission and the attack on Magdala. As he navigates these challenges, he finds a way out by identifying and eliminating the threats, ultimately ending in a better state than when he faced his lowest points. This pattern of falling into a dilemma and finding a way out, ending better than at the beginning, aligns with the "Man in a Hole" story arc type.

### 4. Determined Story Arc Type

Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Sammy, a ten-year-old boy living in the destitution of Corvinton shantytown slum, woke at each dawn to the monotonous singles of a rooster, commencing another relentless day of survival.
2) As dawn broke over the slum, he would embark on arduous tasks, carrying two dilapidated buckets of water from the community well, repairing flimsy asbestos roofs with ancient tools, and dedicating himself to back-breaking labor for a meager reward - a neglected nickel or dime.
3) Back in their ramshackle three-room home, his younger siblings, barely seven and six, made the most of their education from a single dilapidated textbook, a consignment of underwhelming governmental efforts.
4) Meanwhile, his mother, the delicate Rhoda, commenced each grueling day with hushed prayers to a deity she believed was attentive to her pleas, hoping for an end to their dire circumstances.
5) One evening, an altercation among local delinquents obstructed Sammy's path home.
6) Trapped, he found himself drawn into the turmoil, his innate survival instincts ultimately resolving the tense situation.
7) His unforeseen bravery caught the attention of dangerous men involved in the local illegal boxing league - hidden figures in the slum world of Corvinton.
8) Unable to ignore a potential route away from life in the slums, Sammy, more anticipation than trepidation, stepped into a dingy, improvised boxing ring.
9) Fueling his bouts with raw, desperate energy, Sammy started to rack up a trail of victories that only ensnared him deeper into the violent world of underground boxing.
10) Mike Walsh, a once-famous prizefighter now overshadowed by lost opportunities and desolate dreams, observed Sammy's amateur boxing career from the tattered sidelines, seeing potential in the desperate boy.
11) Throwing Sammy a lifeline, Mike offered him a mentorship in fighting.
12) It was the promise of an opportunity for Sammy to escape the crushing poverty of the slums.
13) However, this newfound direction in life was met with vehement resistance at home.
14) Sammy's mother, Rhoda, emphasized that remaining part of this fighting world would only exacerbate their despair.
15) Dismissing his mother's emotional pleas, Sammy committed himself to a course with Mike, creating a challenging mentorship that nurtured his raw capabilities into finesse.
16) Through Mike's rigorous training and strategic insights, Sammy earned recognition beyond the slum, his natural talent refined into a formidable art.
17) Each resounding victory in the boxing ring slowly tapered their past experiences of hunger and debt into vague memories, each subsequent fight win propelling them out of their destitution.
18) But just when rays of hope began to penetrate their grim existence, life struck a devastating blow.
19) Sammy's vivacious younger brother, Caleb, succumbed to a nasty bout with pneumonia.
20) The high cost of medical intervention remained a far-off dream, even with Sammy's burgeoning fight earnings.
21) Faced with this painfully harsh reality, Sammy found himself pushed to extremes, resorting to a perilous path in an attempt to save his brother.
22) He signed up for a notoriously lethal boxing match with monumentally high stakes, its reputation known far beyond the underground circuits of Manhattan.
23) Emerging from the barbaric match covered in blood, Sammy was not only severely injured but also penniless.
24) He had lost the fight and his only chance to save Caleb.
25) Adding to his woes, his devastating defeat cost him a golden opportunity at the statewide boxing heavyweight title.
26) Carrying the burden of broken dreams and physical pain, Sammy trudged home to Rhoda, whose disappointment and sorrow were more wounding than any physical impairment.
27) Sammy wagered everything and yet gained nothing - his prize money had evaporated, Caleb was nearing death, and his mother's faith in him was shattered.
28) Drowning in guilt and despair one morning, he woke in their crumbling shack to the heart-shattering news - Caleb had lost his battle with pneumonia.
29) The grim reality of his loss clouded Sammy's vision, making him question his future in boxing, the only solace he had from the realities of slum life.
30) Confiding in Mike over his uncertainties, Sammy listened to Mike's tales of personal regret and the downward spiral that sank his promising career prematurely.
31) The melancholic story stirred something within Sammy and sparked a reflection on his boxing career and personal life.
32) Encouraged by his mother's disappointed pleas, comforted by prayers, Sammy returned to the worn-out gym, setting himself on a path of redemption and perseverance.
33) Hours slipped into days, and days into weeks as Sammy once again immersed himself in training with renewed spirit and determination sparked by his loss.
34) Ultimately, Sammy once again found himself under the dazzling lights of the statewide boxing arena, surrounded by a lively crowd buzzing with excitement.
35) His cocky opponent, Steven "Iron Knuckles" Green - the arrogant reigning champion, was quick to belittle Sammy's humble origin, snidely dismissing Sammy's place in the ring with him.
36) Provoked by the insults and the unfair reality of his circumstances, Sammy channeled his anger, his pain, his sorrow into the battle amid the electrifying atmosphere of the crowded arena.
37) Their furious fists collided with explosive force, their unwavering spirits locked in a duel of dignity and determination - each aiming to claim the prestigious championship.
38) The showdown was intense, pushing both fighters to their limits, testing their mental fortitude and physical stamina.
39) Yet, against insurmountable odds, Sammy defied the impossible and emerged victorious.
40) His win signified a redemption arc, a badge of resilience, and an unexpected rise to prominence.
41) An unexpected hero of the Corvinton Slum, Sammy lifted the golden championship belt high, his eyes glistening with gratified tears reflected in the victory belt.
42) In the crowd, his mother Rhoda was overcome with emotion.
43) Her tears flowed freely down her worn-out face, rejoicing at her faith in Sammy, which had now been restored.
44) Sammy, the boy once confined to fetching water in bare feet in the shanty, now basked in his triumph as a beacon of hope and embodiment of unyielding determination.
45) Trampling over societal prejudices and expectations, Sammy demonstrated that one’s humble beginning doesn't dictate the future.
46) His momentous victory was not solely his own.
47) It represented Caleb's unfulfilled dreams, whose presence was deeply missed, yet felt with every victory lap.
48) The laurels he earned extended beyond personal acknowledgment; it resonated within Rhoda, within the heart of every slum resident, within the contagious spirit of Caleb.
49) The attained success brought fame, but more importantly, it created an avenue for financial security - a reality alien to his family's previous life.
50) Sammy set aside a part of his winnings to establish The Caleb Foundation in honor of his late brother, ensuring that the children of the slum received proper education and a chance to break free from their cycle of poverty.
51) Caleb's dreams found expression within others, his nonexistence marked by an enduring legacy invoked every time a slum child huddled over a textbook in the newly established learning center.
52) With his newfound managerial status, Sammy started to lobby actively for improved facilities, including clean water and better healthcare services within the shanty.
53) From a neglected street urchin moonlighting as a water carrier to an international icon serving as a beacon of hope, Sammy's trajectory was uplifting and inspiring.
54) Upon reflection, he realized that boxing had not arisen chaos in his life, as his mother had anticipated; instead, it unveiled a world of untapped possibilities and transformative change.
55) From his fresh intervention in a neighborhood clash to the thunderous applause filling the state's largest boxing arena, Sammy understood boxing was, indeed, his destiny.
56) Amid the cacophony of adulation, Sammy clutched his championship belt, a triumphant tear escaping his eyes as he relished his sudden metamorphosis.
57) No longer was he the overlooked barefoot boy wandering the rough streets of Corvinton, but was now a recognized face.
58) Now standing tall as a heavyweight champion, Sammy wasn't just a beacon for the inhabitants of the shantytown, he became the shared voice of anyone who believed in his journey, sharing his struggles and dreams of victory.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
### 1. Identifying the Protagonist and Major Events

The protagonist of the story is Sammy, a ten-year-old boy living in the Corvinton shantytown slum. Here are five major events in the story:

1. **Introduction to Sammy's Life**: Sammy's daily struggle in the slum, including his tasks and his family's situation (sentences 1-4).
2. **Discovery and Entry into Boxing**: Sammy's unforeseen bravery catches the attention of men involved in the local illegal boxing league, leading him to step into boxing (sentences 5-9).
3. **Rise in Boxing and Personal Loss**: Sammy's success in boxing, his decision to continue despite his mother's disapproval, and the tragic loss of his younger brother Caleb (sentences 10-28).
4. **Turning Point and Redemption**: Sammy's realization of his mistakes, his return to boxing with renewed spirit, and his determination to make a better life for himself and his family (sentences 29-33).
5. **Ultimate Victory and Triumph**: Sammy's victory in the statewide boxing championship, his redemption, and the positive impact on his family and community (sentences 34-58).

### 2. Describing the Protagonist's State and Changes

- **Event 1 (Introduction to Sammy's Life)**: Sammy is in a disadvantaged situation, struggling to survive in the slum. His state is one of hardship and desperation.
- **Event 2 (Discovery and Entry into Boxing)**: Sammy's state changes as he finds an opportunity in boxing, which brings him a sense of purpose and potential escape from poverty. His condition improves slightly as he sees a way out of his desperate situation.
- **Event 3 (Rise in Boxing and Personal Loss)**: Despite initial success in boxing, Sammy faces a significant downfall with the loss of his brother and his own physical and emotional struggles. His state worsens due to guilt, despair, and the harsh realities of his actions' consequences.
- **Event 4 (Turning Point and Redemption)**: Sammy's state begins to improve as he reflects on his life, returns to boxing with a renewed spirit, and seeks redemption. He starts to rebuild himself and his future.
- **Event 5 (Ultimate Victory and Triumph)**: Sammy achieves a major victory, both in boxing and in life, as he wins the championship and secures a better future for himself and his community. His state is one of triumph, redemption, and significant improvement from his initial condition.

### 3. Classifying the Story Arc Type

Based on the protagonist's condition throughout the story, the narrative follows a pattern where Sammy rises to a better situation (through boxing), faces significant setbacks (loss of his brother, personal struggles), and ultimately achieves a higher state (winning the championship, finding redemption, and improving his family's and community's situation). This pattern aligns with the **Cinderella** story arc type, where the protagonist rises, faces a setback, and ultimately achieves a higher state. The story showcases Sammy's journey from rags to riches, with a notable period of struggle and loss, followed by redemption and triumph.

### 4. Determined Story Arc Type

Cinderella

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) A young George Foreman lives in poverty in Houston, Texas with his siblings and his religious mother Nancy.
2) Foreman, however, is riddled with anger issues and violent outbursts.
3) As a young adult, Foreman barely evades arrest for mugging and decides to join the Job Corps as a last-ditch effort to turn his life around.
4) There, he befriends his roommate Desmond Baker, however his violent outbursts nearly get him expelled.
5) However, the Job Corps' chairman Doc Broadus, a boxing trainer, encourages Foreman to take up boxing and channel his rage into the sport instead of fighting.
6) Foreman proves to be gifted in the sport and after one year of boxing, he wins the gold medal for the United States against Jonas Čepulis at the 1968 Summer Olympics.
7) He moves to Oakland, California to train, where former champions Dick Sadler and Archie Moore join his team as trainers, and he meets journalist Paula, whom he starts a relationship with and eventually marries.
8) Doc, Paula and Desmond are by his side as Foreman's career flourishes, ultimately winning a fight against Joe Frazier in 1973 and becoming the heavyweight champion.
9) Following his win, Foreman hires Desmond to handle his finances.
10) Foreman's career enables him to live lavishly, however he regularly cheats on Paula with other women and he is dismissive over his mother's attribution of his successes as blessings from God.
11) Foreman is heavily taunted by Muhammad Ali, whom he fights at The Rumble in the Jungle in 1974, where he loses his belt due to Ali's rope-a-dope strategy.
12) Foreman fires Sadler and Moore, and Paula divorces Foreman due to his infidelity.
13) Following an embarrassing Foreman vs. Five match where he is further mocked by Ali, he is called to the hospital where his sister Mary's newborn baby is in poor health.
14) Witnessing his family praying for the baby, Foreman goes outside and angrily prays to God for a sign, offering himself instead of the baby's life.
15) The baby is miraculously saved, and Mary names her son after her brother.
16) After losing to Jimmy Young in 1977, Foreman suffers from a heatstroke and collapses from exhaustion, having near-death experience where he finds himself in a place of nothingness and says that he finally believes before waking up.
17) He becomes a devout Christian and disavows boxing to become a full-time preacher, much to the delight of Nancy and the disappointment of Doc.
18) He makes amends with Ali and Paula for his past behavior towards them.
19) At church, he meets and pursues a relationship with fellow believer Mary Joan Martelly.
20) Years later, Foreman has married Mary Joan and started a family with her.
21) He is a preacher at the Church of the Lord Jesus Christ, and opened a youth community center to help troubled youth.
22) However, in 1985, he realizes the center is in danger of being closed down after finding out he is in debt due to Desmond mishandling his funds.
23) Nancy tells him that despite losing everything, all he needs is already inside him, and he decides to forgive Desmond after confronting him.
24) Foreman's attempts capitalize on his earlier fame is not enough to save the center.
25) He reluctantly decides to return to boxing to earn money, and with Mary Joan and Doc's encouragement, he trains to get back in shape and decides to start his career again from the bottom.
26) Rejecting his prior rage for a more positive outlook, Foreman manages to win several fights and enters a match against Evander Holyfield.
27) Although he loses to Holyfield, the payments from the fight - as well as a profitable deal involving grills - are enough to pay his debts and reopen the center.
28) He works his way up to a match against reigning champion Michael Moorer, which he wins and regains his title as heavyweight champion of the world.
29) Foreman reflects that he had to be knocked down to the bottom to realize everything he was searching for was already there.
30) An epilogue shares that Foreman had become close friends with Ali; Doc was inducted in the World Boxing Hall of Fame in 1998; and Foreman continues to preach at his church and run his youth center in Houston.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
### 1. Identify the Protagonist and Major Events
The protagonist of the story is George Foreman. Five major events in the story are:
1. George Foreman joins the Job Corps as a last-ditch effort to turn his life around (sentence 3).
2. Foreman wins the gold medal for the United States at the 1968 Summer Olympics (sentence 6).
3. Foreman becomes the heavyweight champion after winning a fight against Joe Frazier in 1973 (sentence 8).
4. Foreman has a near-death experience and becomes a devout Christian, disavowing boxing to become a full-time preacher (sentences 16-17).
5. Foreman regains his title as heavyweight champion of the world after winning a match against Michael Moorer (sentence 28).

### 2. Describe the Protagonist's State and Changes
- **Event 1 (Joining Job Corps):** Foreman is at a low point, struggling with anger issues and violent outbursts, but seeking a change. This marks the beginning of his journey towards improvement.
- **Event 2 (Winning Olympic Gold):** Foreman's condition has significantly improved; he has found a positive outlet for his anger (boxing) and is achieving success. This is an upward turn in his life.
- **Event 3 (Becoming Heavyweight Champion):** Foreman reaches a peak in his career and personal life, having overcome his initial struggles and achieved great success. However, this success also leads to personal problems like infidelity.
- **Event 4 (Near-Death Experience and Conversion):** After facing a series of setbacks, including losing his championship and his marriage, Foreman hits a spiritual low but then experiences a profound personal transformation, becoming a devout Christian. This marks a significant change in his personal life, as he seeks redemption and a new path.
- **Event 5 (Regaining Heavyweight Title):** Foreman's condition has improved again; he has not only regained his physical prowess and boxing title but has also found a new sense of purpose and peace through his faith. This event shows that Foreman has come full circle, achieving success once more but this time with a deeper understanding of himself and his values.

### 3. Classify the Story Arc Type
The story follows George Foreman through two major cycles of improvement and decline. Initially, he rises from a life of poverty and violence to become a successful boxer, which can be seen as the first "man in a hole" scenario where he improves his condition. However, he then falls into another dilemma due to his personal issues and losses, only to find his way out again through his spiritual transformation and eventual return to boxing, culminating in regaining his championship title. This pattern of falling into a dilemma, finding a way out, and then facing another dilemma before ultimately recovering and ending in a better state than where he started is characteristic of the **Double Man in a Hole** story arc.

### 4. Determined Story Arc Type
Double Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) The narrative unfolds in the frost-bitten, hushed town of Eugene, Oregon in the icy grips of winter in 1995.
2) The narrative starts in an ivy-clad Victorian household, surrounded by a deafening silence, punctuated only by the whimpering of a child.
3) Here, Ethan, a blond-haired four-year-old angel, huddles helplessly under his bed late one frosty night; his limbs crippled, his voice a pained whisper.
4) The disturbing scene of her whimpering brother is discovered by Emily, Ethan's six-year-old sister.
5) Chilled to the bone with the unfolding of a horrifying inexplicability, Emily's initial shock morphs into a resolute determination to uncover the ghastly mystery of her brother's condition.
6) Driven by a personal quest, Emily heads towards a future with a specialized focus on sleep disorders in her formative years.
7) Emily's life takes an unexpected turn when she receives a frantic call from a terrified mother in Salem, whose son’s sleepwalking episodes are reminiscent of the spine-chilling narratives of Ethan's past.
8) Touched by the heartfelt plea, Emily feels the weight of the challenge ahead.
9) Yet, her resolve to help remains unshakable.
10) With a strengthened resolve, Emily commences her voyage of intervention and exploration.
11) As Emily delves deeper into the intricacies of the afflicted child's psyche, a string of terrifying episodes unfurls.
12) Skirting at the edge of rationale, Emily's investigation takes a daunting turn.
13) She contemplates the potential intervention of a supernatural force behind the terrifying sleepwalking episodes.
14) Moved by an overwhelming determination to protect the boy and unravel the truth, Emily decides to induce sleepwalking within herself.
15) As sleep envelops her, Emily experiences an uncharted realm tickling her consciousness.
16) Emily finds herself walking the unfamiliar, spectral terrains.
17) Despite the bone-chilling fear, Emily trudges forward.
18) As Emily progresses further, she learns about the spirit’s resentment.
19) Emily’s journey into the spectral realms and the downward spiral into her own family’s tragedy results in empathising with the spirit.
20) Inside the phantasmal realm, Emily discovers an unexpected silver lining.
21) She finds a channel of communication opening up between her and Ethan.
22) Emily begins to empathise with the spirit.
23) As Emily realises that the spirit's torment and curse were bound by the memories of the spirit's heinous experiences of familial betrayal and abuse, Emily and Ethan pledge to honour and remember the spirit.
24) As the resonance of their promise reverberates through the spectral expanse, Emily finds herself jolted awake from her induced sleepwalking.
25) Emily begins her mission to implement the discoveries from her spectral quests.
26) Each day, Emily immerses herself to apply the newfound practices and strategies.
27) Alongside her endeavouring to heal affected children, Emily also begins to mend her frayed bond with Ethan.
28) Their shared trauma, once a curse, slowly becomes the catalyst that was imperative to healing their once strained bond.
29) Running parallel to Emily’s growing success in her professional life, her personal life also begins to bloom.
30) The relationship with Ethan, once strained and disconnected, begins to flourish, marked with shared understanding and empathy.
31) Emily evolves into a beacon of hope.
32) Emily emerges with a newfound identity – a courageous healer, determined to battle the vengeful spirit and aid the afflicted children battling sleepwalking disorders.
33) They begin to unearth buried feelings, echoing sentiments of shared trauma that they had silently borne in their respective hearts.
34) Emily's unwavering pursuit of truth and healing rescues not just the sleepwalking children but also brings Ethan back from his self-exile.
35) Emily’s refusal to surrender to fear paves the path to peace, understanding, and healing in an otherwise tormented landscape that had only know suffering.
36) Emily’s transformative journey touches not just her immediate circle of influence, but reaches out far beyond.
37) Word of her success spreads throughout the city of Eugene, and her influence expands.
38) The narrative embodies a tale of empathy, resilience, and redemption from adversity.
39) It celebrates the raw human grit and the power of familial unity that serves as the driving forces of healing.
40) With her encounters in the spectral realm and her realization of therapeutic powers, Emily emerges as a hero that the afflicted sleepwalkers desperately needed.
41) The film reaffirms the belief that fear can only dominate us until we muster the courage to face it.
42) Emily's courageous confrontation with the vindictive spirit serves as a testament to this.
43) Ethan and Emily’s shared tale underlines the importance of preserving familial bonds through trials.
44) It amplifies the healing power that unity can provide.
45) Packed with emotional depth, fear, courage, resilience, hope, and a tale of recovery, the narrative gives a gripping cinematic experience.
46) The unraveling of the mystery of the sleepwalking curse, Emily's dangerous expeditions through the spectral realm, and her resilient spirit converge to sculpt a unique cinematic narrative.

output:
